text:
Employment

A new departure in co-operative between workingmen and employers is the National Employment Exchange, just opened in N.Y.C. Its aim is the providing of a place where skilled workmen of all kinds can congregate mornings for the purpose of being interviewed by prospective employers.

From Photo-News Dept.
American Press Assoc.
225 W. 39th St., N.Y.

c. 1917
title: Manhattan: Cooper Square - [Employment.]

folder: Cooper Square (North) & Between 5th and 6th Streets (East)., Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Cooper Square, east side, north from and including East 5th Street, to but not including East 6th Street. A 4-story frame house is located on the N.E. corner of East 5th Street.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York. Negative No. 144.

(2)
The same, from 5th Street. February, 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, showing a closer view. March 30, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Cooper Square (North) & 4th Street (East) & [Cooper Union Institute.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Cooper Square, north from East 4th Street, showing Fourth and Third Aves. converging to form at their apex, the Bowery. Surface cars from both lines are seen in the foreground with the Third Ave. Elevated overhead. In the center appears the Cooper Union Institute, founded by Peter Cooper.
February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing a closer view of the Cooper Union Institute.
July 7, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, north from E. 5th Street.
Sept. 20, 1935

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Cooper Square (North) - 5th Street (East) - [Cooper Union Institute.]

folder: Cooper Square (North) & 6th Street (East) & Astor Place., Manhattan, NY
text:
Cooper Square, east side, north from, but not including East 6th Street to Astor Place, showing Cooper Park; a triangular area between East 6th and 7th Streets. Directly north of same, is the Cooper Union Institute, and facing (side with clock) on East 7th Street. Fourth Ave., which starts at this point, forms the western side. At the extreme north end of the park is a statue of Peter Cooper; the founder.

January 13, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

The Institute according to the New York Times of July 7, 1938 is undergoing general renovations, consisting mainly of repainting the exterior and reconstruction of the original elevator cage and shaft. This structure, often credited with being Manhattan's first "sky-scraper," was started in 1856 by the founder, and is said to be the first building in which iron was used as part of the interior framework. Since no iron girders were being manufactured at that time, Cooper utilized ordinary railroad rails from his iron mills in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for the floor beams and arches. Since it was completed in 1859, the finish has been a dark reddish brown to match the brownstone which comprises most of the exterior. A warm sandstone color is now being applied to bring out the architectural details; the old reddish brown paint being used only on the exterior of the fourth and fifth floors, which were constructed of Caen stone because labor difficulties halted the shipments of brownstone in 1858. The elevator was installed around 1863 and was incorporated in a cylindrical shaft. The major change here is the reconstruction of the cage.
title: Manhattan: Cooper Square (North) - 6th Street (East) - Astor Place
